<question>



Please help me with accessorising this dress. Pictures included.?



I'm going out to a formal event and I want to wear a vintage dress with a modern twist, but I'm not sure how to accessorise it, so I need some help!



This is the dress. I'll be shortening it so it'll be above the knees, so please try to picture it that way! And just so you know, the shoulders are see through:
http://i34.tinypic.com/20pvii8.jpg



Once modified, should I wear it:
a) with no stockings
b) with these stockings: http://flickr.com/photos/8545733@N05/286...
c) with sheer black stockings
d) other?



Should I wear it as it is, or throw on



a) a black cinch belt like this one:
http://i34.tinypic.com/xdi9s0.jpg
b) other?



I definitely want oxford peep toe pumps, but what colour should I get?
a) white like these:
http://i38.tinypic.com/2dkkcax.jpg
b) the same as above but in black
c) the same as above but in black AND white?



I'm sort of going a for a black/white look, since I was inspired by Audrey Hepburn's white dress in My Fair Lady. (Looks like this:)
http://i34.tinypic.com/5zgy1t.jpg



If anyone can think of jewelry or hair accessories that match, please put in suggestions. Pictures would be so helpful, and I'd love it if you could give me your opinions on which shoes to wear with which hosiery. I want to look like I just stepped off the runway. Thanks so much!



</question>

<answer>



well, the only thing i ever got from there was crap, and their customer service was down-right rude, so i will never be shoping there again.



they had this ring on-line, it was silver plated, just a basic plain band, and it was really pretty ($150) so my fiance got it for me for christmas.  i put it on as soon as i opened it, and by dinner that night my finger started turning green.  i wasnt happy, but i know everyone reacts differently so i was going to deal with it and just put some clear nail polish on it the next day.  well, i fell asleep with it on, and by the next morning it had rusted around the entire inside, and where it was touching my other 2 fingers!!  i brought it back to the store that day and the woman who was "helping" me had the nerve to tell me it was "supposed to do that" since it was only plated.  her exact words.  so i asked her to refund my fiance's credit card, which she rolled her eyes at.



so my fiance has lucked out and will never ever have to even look at that store again.



</answer>

<question>



What is a maxi dress?



im shopping for a friends wedding and im just wondering what a maxi dress is



</question>



<answer from>



Fran H
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 830 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A long dress



</answer>



<answer from>



monkeyso...
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 83 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's an ankle length dress.



</answer>



<answer from>



Olivia -
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 2411 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Length of Skirts and Dresses are



Mini - (Mini skirt, short skirt/dress above the knee)
Midi - (just below the knee)
Maxi - (floor length)



These are some maxi dresses http://s3.amazonaws.com/stylehive/blog/u...



</answer>



<answer from>



little miss sunshine x3
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 952 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A maxi dress is a dress that goes down to your ankles, or to the floor.



</answer>

<answer from>



Phat T

Total points: 1812 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A lot of colours clash with orange, but it can be done! Black goes with anything, but it may scream out halloween if it's a bright orange. Grey would work if it's a light orange, and white also will go. I guess it depends on the shade of the scarf. I don't think pink, red, or yellow would go, as they are too similar, and green/aqua/bright blues would probably clash. Purple and brown will go nicely :D



</answer>

i am six foot......yes i am a girl..and yes i am quite slender.

<question>



Do you think Hanging up heavy sweaters would ruin them?



I hung up my Boyfriends Thick Heavy Sweater on a hanger and put it in the closet. A few days later he removed it and told me that by doing so i streched the neck of the sweater because it was too heavy to be put on a hanger...has anyone ever heard of such a thing before? I just want to know if anyone else would know that that could happen.



</question>



<answer from>



Lauren Ashleigh
Member since: 04 July 2007
Total points: 443 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes, putting heavy sweaters on hangers does stretch the neck.
if you fold them up they will be just fine.
after you wash it again, it may not be so stretched out anymore.



</answer>



<answer from>



babebabe...
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 15329 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes!  Hanging sweaters will stretch the shoulders and leave hanger marks.  Heavy sweaters should be folded and put on a shelf or in a drawer.  Besides what are you trying to do, teach your boyfriend you're his maid?  He should be picking up after himself, not you doing it!



</answer>



<answer from>



Amy W
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



lol yea ii have done that to  mine! it made me mad! that sweater was to heavy so has it hung on tha hanger it got stretched out..



</answer>



<answer from>



lmkbabe1...
Member since: 25 June 2008

</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



gothchiq
Member since: 25 May 2006
Total points: 607 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends. You can do it if you use a padded hanger, but not any other kind.



</answer>



<answer from>



Marty74
Member since: 13 December 2007
Total points: 3256 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



amber - you are supposed to flat dry those kind of things... ie, lie them on a table etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



tracydaw...
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 228 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know it can make those little indentations in the shoulders of sweaters. Also, if the sweater is bottom heavy, it could stretch the whole thing out causing holes to appear all through the sweater. I hang all my sweaters up but have been thinking of buying a large dresser so I don't have to deal with messy stretched sweaters any longer!



</answer>



<answer from>



Kirsty S
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Absolutely. This is very true. Heavy sweaters should not be hung from hangers. They should be drooped over, like drooping them over the back of a chair until they dry. The reason, is because the fabric is so heavy when wet, it actually ruins the shape of the sweater due to the weight of the fabric stretching the garment against the hanger.



Next time, put it on a backrest of a chair.



</answer>

<original file>11078.html</original file>

<category>



Beauty & Style



Fashion & Accessories



</category>



<question from>



Kirsty S
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What would you do if you lost your high heels during a client meeting!?



Its not that simple, I went to a client meeting at a construction site in my pinstripe tailored suit, with matching pencil skirt, tan nylons and a pair of black peep toe patent leather Gucci stilettos. Unfortunately, the night before it rained a lot and when I reached the construction site there was no one there. I called my client and he told me they were already on the 7th floor and to make my way there. I noticed a small wooden gangplank leading from the sidewalk all the way across the incredibly muddy site to the cemented ground floor of the apartment block being built. Suffice it to say halfway across the rickety and narrow wooden beams, that were still wet from the showers the night before, I stumbled, and as I didn't want to fall face first into the mud, I moved my feet in front to try and stop myself from falling. Unfortunately, both my feet went straight in the mud and I sank to my knees in incredibly, horrifically cold sticky mud!! I screamed for help and luckily a few site workers rushed to help me. Here comes the worst part though… As soon as they pulled me out I immediately felt suction building against my feet and felt the cold mud pouring into my shoes! Yes, they were coming of me! I told them to stop pulling me, but they didn't listen and as a consequence out I came without my shoes!!! What would you do?



</question>



<answer from>



steph t
Member since: 05 March 2008
Total points: 1186 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



PLEASE READ:
ArrrG! What a disaster never mind the embarrassment that you must have experienced its the shoes that are more important! lolz.. no doubt they was really expensive and i feel for you- but there is nothing you can do really.. mud is a difficult thing to get out of clothes never mind shoes- so if you was to fish them out of the mud they wud be ruined- after all you can not put them in the washing machine (well i suppose you could try i guess). I think the best thing to do is to move on and compensate your loss with a brand new pair of gucci shoes.. this way you will forget all about your loss.. above all you should seriously think about suing the company after all construction site is really dangerous and you was lucky not to hurt yourself.. goodness knows what would happened if it was a old person or child.. Style should never be compromised so dont listen to others who tell you to bring sneakers (or has we in the uk call them trainers loz) just go careful next time!!
Hope This Helps x



Source(s):



PLEASE VOTE FOR THE BEST ANSWER x



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks, luckily I did as you suggested the following day and bought a new pair to make the pain go away! Unfortunately, I didn't have a change of shoes, so I called the client and told him I had a family emergency and re-scheduled.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Stryder S
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 1125 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



not wear expensive shoes...or maybe keep sneakers in trunk for situations just like this.  Proper planning prevents piss poor practice.



</answer>



<answer from>



im the man wif the plan

<answer>



charity shop?



</answer>



<answer from>



Seafret1...
Member since: 30 April 2008
Total points: 1042 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could try E-bay for that classic "Smurfet" white shift dress.  BHS had some in for less than 20 pounds this summer, but, as we are now moving into winter stock, you may have difficulty finding one in the right size in the sales!
The first person had a good idea for you to browse the charity shops/boot sales in your area too.  People who buy white dresses often regret it afterwards if they are like me and a muck magnet.
Good luck in your search, have you got fab huge white shoes to go with it and the sexy hat? Lol.



</answer>

<question>



Does anyone want to buy an authentic Prada Fairies Bag?



One of Prada's newest designs, the Prada Fairy Bag has quickly become a hot item. Featuring an artistic drawing of fairies in black, plum, and earth tones, the bag has been spotted on the arms of several celebrities including Sienna Miller,Hillary Duff, Tilda Swiden, and Jennifer Love Hewitt, which may have contributed to it selling out at Neiman Marcus in just 2 days. Made of deerskin leather it's a very simple shape with top handles and measures 10 1/5" x 14 1/5" x 6".



Only a limited amount of these bags were made. There is a waitlist about a mile long for this bag and it is extremely difficult to get on to. This bag is hot, hot, hot right now!



This bag combines art, fashion, and top quality. It is unique. It is less about fashion and more about art. So for those who want to embrace and tote around art and design, this is the perfect bag. Rarely do you find such artistic work combined with a top quality designer bag. This bag is not like any other designer bag you own and will most likely be a collectible item. This bag is quite unique to say the least.



This bag is an unwanted present off an unwanted contact that will make someone very lucky to own one of the very few Prada Fairy Bags out there. A Dust cover is included with this bag along with a certificate of Authencity.



Leave your email address and i will post you pictures. Thanks



</question>

Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I hope youre somewhere warm!
If so go for a patterned top with white in it. Two block colours ie white trousers and a plain top, look dull. Unless you've got some fab big jewellery to make it more interesting?



</answer>

<answer from>



Rick A
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 1243 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



We had one of these at my school and I dressed up with all used clothes I bought at my local thrift store. The shoes were these massive platforms in two-tone leather. Really cool stuff. My girlfriend ending up wearing a Laugh In type Go Go outfit with flowers and a leather vest with a yellow belt that was studded. Both of us found a fringed leather vest, which really looked razed, totally cool.  I actually like shopping at the thrift stores and finding vintage leather vests and boots. You can find so many vintage clothes for this period and You already have most of your outfit. You will look  glam  with the right shoes.



I like the leggings, denim mini skirt but the sweater, I don't know? Maybe a flower rayon blouse or a flower print? The shoes most definitely should be platforms, If you can find a pair in your size.



I think a great pair of platforms , shoes, or boots would look glam and very fitting. If you have a local thrift store or Goodwill I would think you could find lots of really cool clothes and several pair of platform shoes. Groovy time ahead so make the look all your own with  a peace symbol.



Source(s):



http://rds.yahoo.com/_ylt=A0geu6F8oONIh0...



If you have time look at Vintage 80's clothes;  at Ebay.com



</answer>

<question>



How can you safely wash jeans with paint on them?



I got paint on my jeans, let it dry, and then washed them. I want the paint to stay how it is on the jeans but if I put them in the dryer won't the paint melt or something?



</question>



<answer from>



Tina W
Member since: 14 May 2007
Total points: 3075 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know if the paint would melt.. but you could put the pants into a plain pillowcase, put them on the gentle cycle with gentle detergent. Woolite, or Dreft would work, then hang them up to dry.



</answer>



<answer from>



RUNINTLK...
Member since: 21 December 2005
Total points: 5967 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Keep doing what you're doing.  I wouldn't put them in the dryer.



Paint fumes, heat/flammable..you never know.



Wash & Air Dry.  Eventually the paint will come off, but you can enjoy it for a while.



</answer>



<answer from>



heineken
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When u wash it turn it inside out and take it out of the dryer when its slightly damp..



</answer>



<answer from>



mike1942...
Member since: 25 December 2006
Total points: 62949 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on the paint.



You should have chosen something that you have defined cleaning directions for.



Most paints, if they survive the washing part will not "melt" in the dryer.  You may have to hand wash and hang dry.



</answer>

<question>



What is the best or average inseam size for someone whos  4'11'' ?



thanks



</question>



<additional details>

</answer from>



<answer>



well you're what, about 212 lbs, so i'd say best case scenario is, about 20 inches



</answer>



<answer from>



Bekka
Member since: 20 September 2006
Total points: 7521 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Um... it really isn't going to matter now is it?  We can quote you "perfect" all day long - but in the end, you cannot change the length of your inseam.



I would suggest loving what you've got - buy clothes, have them tailored to fit (it doesn't cost that much and usually your local dry-cleaner can do it or recommend someone)....



Nothing anyone says here is going to change the fact that your inseam is the length that it is... "best" "average" or "perfect" should redefine who you are.



Love yourself no matter what!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



syc
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



2cm?
because that's the average size for everyone and is probably on every hand made garment
but in factory's it's 1.5 cm
height hasn't got much to do with seams and being slim doesn't really affect it either
it all depends on how much fabric you cut out.
in case you cut too much u can make d seam bigger and just cut it off if it's loads of left overs.
hope this helped =p
i did textiles



</answer>

<original file>13567.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk23966.txt</current file name>




<category>



Beauty & Style



Fashion & Accessories



</category>



<question from>



kate
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What kind of swimsuit would suit me?



so i need a new swimsuit but im not sure what to get. Because im not "fat",but i have a bit just above where my pants sit where it goes out then back in,sort of like a roll,but not a roll.And im also very short.



Examples with pictures would be appreciated,thankyou :D



</question>



<answer from>



Emo**...
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 431 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Too many times women will fall in love with a swimsuit in the store and then never put it on again. Why does this happen? The main reason is that the suit isn't practical for active use. When buying a swimsuit there are some important considerations to look at before buying, not the least of which is whether you are going to be active in it, like playing volleyball or just lying in the sun.



Let's take a look at some of the things we want to consider.



First off, you want to choose the right suit for your body type. For example, if you have wide hips or a little bit of a tummy you want to use blocks of color on one-piece suits constructed of darker fabric on the bottom and a lighter top half. You also want at least 15% spandex.



If you aren't naturally or otherwise endowed in the top, choose a lightly padded halter or a bra style with an underwire. You can also divert attention away from a smaller bust by using suits with texture and small print designs.



If you have the opposite problem or blessing, whichever way you want to look at it, you can minimize a larger chest by wearing a darker top with a higher neck. Make sure that the suit offers the support you need and choose a wider bottom to give you balance.



For a small or petite frame, a one piece with thin vertical striping can help and you can make short legs look longer with a higher cut on the hip. If you have a boyish figure, you can give yourself the illusion of a smaller waistline with a tankini and if you have what you consider to be an overly round bottom you can wear a "skort", the short and skirt combination to divert attention.



If you are one of the lucky ones with nice toned legs and shoulders, show them off with a bikini or a more revealing one piece.



These days, you can mix and match tops and bottoms when buying bikinis, so have fun with that. Just remember what you are going to use the suit for. If you plan on being in the water a lot you may not want a light thin material, unless you are an exhibitionist!



If you are going to be doing some kind of athletic activity you wan to be sure that you have the proper support so that you don't end up falling out while jumping for a volleyball.



http://cgi.ebay.com/Size-16-Swimsuit-SLI...



Wear those swimsuit that will cover your body perhaps? if not then wear bikinis ..or what Girli suggested,a tankini.



Source(s):



http://www.streetdirectory.com/travel_gu...



http://cgi.ebay.com/Size-16-Swimsuit-SLI...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



wow.thankyou so much. i never really thought of all that.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Girli
Member since: 07 May 2007
Total points: 1659 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www2.victoriassecret.com/commerce...



a tankini like this would be great on you and would cover up that area your worried about.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chantel S

</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

rts777

<question from>

<question>



I'm so afraid that my dreams of becoming a fashion Designer may not happen? ?



I'm 17...I've wanted this since my 12 birthday, which was when I flipped through my first issue of vogue magazine.



However, I think it just hit me how competitive it is out there. I've been working on my portfolio for design school for over a year (I still have 2 to go) . A lot of people say I'm talented, I do internships at boutiquesand ateliers, I take life drawing classes, I learn to sew..



Is there anything else I can do? I love clothing so much. For me...fashion means rrebellion means expressing yourself, not having to stick to rules...



</question>



<answer from>



Rach
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 262 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am 13 now and I have had a dream of being a designer since I was 7 and yeah it may be a tough business to get into but with good will adn determination you will get there I can guarantee it



</answer>

Member since: 28 September 2008

</question>



<answer from>



Emo-RoXa...
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 473 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I'd also suggest looking for it in the spring, around April. This way, you won't be last minute shopping one month before grad, and you will have a larger selection to choose from. The father away grad is, the better chance you have of getting a dress.
Again, burgundy. You'd look amazing in a brown or burgundy. Maybe a really dark red will work too.
lol



</answer>

<answer from>



ssandyde...
Member since: 15 August 2006

</answer from>



<answer>



do u want a formal semi formal or just a dress. if formal or semi then u want to start now last years models are on sale and it is not the big bridal time. if u wait til after jan u will pay 10 times as much as u will now.  if u want a regular dress then anytime is good. pennies and Macy's have marked their formals down we were just there they are still expensive but under $100 for the most part. at grad time u will pay over 300 good luck



</answer>

around march or april..thats around the time when the spring dresses come out..i graduated a while ago but I got a really cute casual springy dress from davids bridal and i ended up wearing it a couple times after graduation, so when it come time you should look there

<current file name>yqa_uk24628.txt</current file name>




<category>



Beauty & Style



Fashion & Accessories



</category>



<question from>



intplcom
Member since: 26 October 2006
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can i wear a metal watch with my wedding suit or not?



</question>



<answer from>



x
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 388 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



course u can



xx



</answer>



<answer from>



Gene
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 314 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes u can



</answer>



<answer from>



Emily !
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Congrats anyway! :P Defanatly! Your suit will probley cover it anyway!



</answer>



<answer from>



Kshizzle
Member since: 23 February 2008
Total points: 2255 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



it depends



1. if your suit has any gold detailing or you have a golden toned theme color for the wedding, do NOT wear a silver watch. as for the reverse as well, a silver weding and a gold watch will not match



2. If its silver which it probably is, it would go with any color, other than gold and yellow, so put that into account



3. And an easy way to knwo is to look at your fiances jewelry for the event, gold pearls and a gold bracelet obviously match with your GOLD watch, but silver jewelry would go with your SILVER watch =]



Have fun and congrats on the wedding!
xx



</answer>

<original file>3623.html</original file>

<category>



Beauty & Style



Fashion & Accessories



</category>



<question from>



MICHELLE B
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 52 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Lord of the Rings Dresses based on which Countries Clothing?



I mean, the dresses worn by Arwen , Eowyn and Galadriel. The designs and such, does anybody have any Idea what country the designs of these dresses and fashion were based upon. Hope you can help, thanks.



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks all your answers helped me a lot, now I can work on the cultures they are based on. Never knew some were inspired by Ireland, great! Thanks.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Calliope
Member since: 16 August 2006
Total points: 4497 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



They aren't based on a particular culture, they are based more on a time period and genre, those being medieval and fantasy.



The cultural roots for these designs are usually based around European dress during the medieval and renaissance period.  Ireland, Scotland, England, France, Spain, Italy, Greece, Scandinavian...etc.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks that helped line it out for me, I never knew it was inspired by Ireland as well, Great stuff! Thanks.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



katie s
Member since: 10 April 2007
Total points: 2402 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A lot of them are renaissance era peasant dresses from Ireland, especially Eowen's dresses.



</answer>



<answer from>



jewelore...
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 476 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They are based on Celtic designs.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tori J
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer>



I think the black one looks better. However if you want to stand out you should get the pink ones definitly. The black one however will go with anything you wear and if you change a bit (fashion sense wise) the black shoes will still be fine for you where as the pink one may go against your new styles or likes. When pink shoes get dirty they tend to look real cheap and makes the person look cheap and dirty. But if you get the black ones, not only will they appear cleaner and you won't have to clean them much, if they do get dirty or look like as if it's wearing out a bit, it gives you a pretty cool look i rekon!



Also remember that you are seeing this from the computer screen in professional photos, the pink may not be as appealing as it looks with the clean white background and shiny tips etc!



Hope that helps



</answer>

thnk u! ur answer made me laugh & its sweet! and thnks evry 1 else! i loved all ur answers! :)

<answer from>



Maddy
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 903 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Good question.  The common suggestions, or ideas of the answers previously submitted are ones, that in my opinion, are the first thoughts most people have when trying to build a young persons confidence level.
I agree with them, HOWEVER, I also know how important it is for some of us to "fit in" and/or be accepted into today's society; especially at school.  Middle school and high school girls are, by any definition, the meanest and nastiest of any group of individuals. And, to be cast out by a group one wants to be a part of is a HUGE blow to the ego and self esteem.  So, with that said  -



You must search your own self and determine HOW important it is to be accepted into the "in crowd".  If this group of people are the ones you determine are important to your "rank" at school, then you must conform to the accepted dress code that has been established by the high ranking popular students.



As adults we, for the most part, find this behavior petty, rude and unacceptable.  However on the on the opposite of that statement, the same behavior is often found among adult groups, no matter how much we want to believe this is not the case.
So, to sum up what I have already said, it is ultimately up to you as to how you dress and what accessories you deem proper.  If you find you are looked down upon by those to whom you aspire to emulate, you must loose your current style and connect with the styles of your future peers.
If you are not concerned with "fitting in"; which I will safely assume by your posting query, is not the case.
To quote the rock group "Rush" - "conform or be cast out".....
Good luck I hope you find your place.



</answer>



<answer from>



countri girl
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If it makes you feel any better, I'm dealing with the same thing. People always say to be yourself. Maybe that's wisest. But these same people seem to have forgotten what social life at school was like. The US government and the gods on Mount Olympus have nothing on girl's cliques both hierarchy-wise and governmentally. Its a lot of stress, and sometimes one has to bend to meet social standards.



Social connections are very important to get places in life, and you usually have to be publicly acceptable and maybe a little popular to establish them. However, being yourself is still very important. Its called compromise. Adapt to fashion trends, but make sure you spice it all up a little with YOUR STYLE. Switch off between a tote and ur back pack during the school week, or something like that. You decide how your going to organize it. Blending in...not good. Unless the situation calls for it, becoming completely camouflaged in society is giving in to mediocrity and anonymity in some ways. Stick out. Don't be anonymous.



I think your backpack is really cool.



Source(s):



Previous experience



</answer>

I just eat healthily.



Hahaha, anyway.
Is there anything I can do to look better in my wardrobe, particularly in t-shirts now that summer's coming? I'm not interested in completely changing the way I dress. I was told to wear babydolls and flowy dresses, and I was way too self-consious to pull them off. Is there anything I can look out for to help me look thinner? <answer>



Babydolls are a nono
they puff out making you look muuccch bigger.
yes admitably black does make you look thiner... however its bland if you wear black all over.
wear bold colours on top, say a bold tee with nothing on it and jeans and then a bold colour converse.
stripes only make you look thiner if they are vertical, horizontal makes you look larger.
try wearing statement accessories as well, like large chunky necklaces and bangles, this draws attention to them, also large bags work for this too.
its going into summer now so get rid of the tees and jeans, why not try a pencil skirt these shape your curves and make you look thinner, also throw a bolero on top :)



</answer>

next season they are virtually out anyhow....



go for baggy jeans and you can keep the hood if you like... DON't wear anything which shows your abdomen tyres please, it's a no no.... as are jeans which are tight at hips and make your fat bulge when you sit.. or in some cases even when walking....



you don't have to wear flowery dresses, it doesn't seem to be your style...  try to avoid light colours if you are big.. no horizontal stripes, vertical stripes are fine. vertical patterns are fine...



if you're not tall don't wear baby doll dresses,  however there are these skirts which are knee length and baggy, gypsyish... hope this helps

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Shrinking jeans in a bath.?



I heard if you wear your jeans and sit in a bathtub for half an hour they shrink to your size. But do you use hot or cold water?



</question>



<answer from>



Kirsty...
Member since: 07 November 2007
Total points: 5963 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hot Water,



Same Logic as a washing Machine.
When you put stuff on too high a heat it shrinks (same with a dryer)
That's why with important items, you put them on a cool wash.



I don't think this actually works though. The water would have to be really hot. To hot for you to stand sitting in.
Don't try cold either, you'll get pneumonia.



I would suggest taking them in at the seams with a sewing machine!



</answer>



<answer from>



ere тo нelp
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 404 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most probably hot because when you wash clothes at a hot temp. they usually shrink



hope this helps u babe
xx



</answer>



<answer from>



Tiffany P
Member since: 07 July 2007
Total points: 476 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its easier to just put them in the washing machine. Just make sure you use the hottest water you have. Once the machine fills open the lid and let them sit for a few minutes. That way once they sit you can let the cycle run and spin them out. Then put them in a hot dryer. Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Roberto
Member since: 16 June 2006
Total points: 478 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



tumble dry with a piece of Bounce always worked for me. can't keep cotton from shrinking in the dryer.



</answer>



<answer from>



bg
Member since: 05 November 2007
Total points: 474 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



its funny i read the pposite thing abt it 2 days ago and tried to stretch my jeans using the same method only yesterday. it's still drying so i dont know if it stretched or not. hopefully it didnt shrink! lol... unfortunately for me i couldn't use hot or warm water cus i know for a fact that hot water shrinks jeans. it was too cold to be in the tub full of cold water...so i kinda gave up on it.
the best thing for u to do would be to wash ur jeans in a hot water cycle and dry in very hot setting in the dryer. it helped me to get a pair of size 3 jeans wearably resized. I'm a size 1. hope this helps.



</answer>

<question>



How do you get pen marks out of clothing?



I found a blue pen mark on my white hoodie :(
It's not real dark, but it's long.  I heard about using hairspray to get it out, but does it work? I'm just looking for experience from others before I go and ruin it.



</question>



<answer from>



Roberto
Member since: 16 June 2006
Total points: 496 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Alcohol.
Use one of them little swab thingies that you rip open and put on a scratch. You can find them in first aid kits. I used to order extra packs 'cause I was always putting my pen in my pocket before clicking it closed.
Wipe up, wipe down. GONE!



</answer>

Abinaya .
Member since: 01 October 2008

<question from>



speakyou...
Member since: 14 September 2008

</question from>



<question>



Please help me on this fashion question?



Hi, can you help me on this question?



a) When Dan puts his newly made shirt on, the stripes are on the angle instead of vertical.



1) What went wrong, which step did Dan miss?



2) What could he have done to have a better result? Which procedure should he have used to avoid the stripes being on an angle?



Thanks!!



</question>



<answer from>



Yohan J
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 1156 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The cut of the shirt may have been the problem... Was the material positioned correctly when it was cut??



To fix or prevent this problem, make sure that the cloth is correctly positioned and marked out before it is cut out and sewn together.



</answer>



<answer from>



shiveshs...
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 8736 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



WASH OUT THE SHIRT WITH STARCH SIOLUTION.
GET IT IRONED PROPERLY



</answer>

<answer>



Go to the zoo. Howler monkeys are big, usually pretty mean (sometimes), so the zookeeper won't mind you shooting a couple from the herd.  It'll save them money on food, too. Just try not to make a big mess with all the blood and brains. You should shoot 'em in the head - cuz it'll save bullet holes in the skin. <original file>7671.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk31052.txt</current file name>




<category>



Beauty & Style



Fashion & Accessories



</category>



<question from>



Lee
Member since: 02 January 2007
Total points: 650 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Glue on garment!!!Help!!!?



what can i use to get glue off my jacket which accidentally spilt there?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on what the jacket is made of and how hard the glue is. Without knowing that, I would hazard a guess and suggest that if the glue is hard, you may be able to scrape it off very gently using a non serrated, smooth plastic knife. I would like to suggest nail polish remover which will work with some fabrics, but could wreck others. You could try a little on a hidden area of a jacket, but I think the best idea as I don't know enough about your fabric, type of glue, etc. would be to take it to a dry cleaners. They may be able to simply spot clean. Best of luck.



</answer>

<question>



What should I wear to an interview ?



for a bar person



</question>



<answer from>



Xalan
Member since: 18 June 2006
Total points: 363 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi!



I suggest you take a trip to the bar you will be working in and see what the women there wear. Wear something similar to your interview - they will find it easier to see you in the job if what you wear is close to what their employees wear.



Good luck
Alan



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Jess
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 206 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would wear black slacks as it is required for most bartenders and closed toed shoes are a must for working in the service industry.  I guess I recommend going by the old adage of dressing for the job that you want- so they know that you'll be presentable if you get the job.



As for the top, that depends on the bar.  You'd wear a different top for a biker bar than a martini bar.  If it's a scene bar wear something hip but not revealing.  Let them have a hint at your personality so they'll know you'll fit in but keep it professional.



Source(s):



Retired bartender



</answer>



<answer from>



grah1200...
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 330 (Level 2)



</answer from>

good luck



</answer>

Member since: 18 April 2007

<question from>



Ƨʈɸѝєᴙ ©ħǃɔК
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is This Normal?? Piercing?



Okay, I got my ears pierced on Saturday. My dad did it with one of those at home piercing kits. I clean my ears everyday 2-3 times a day with the stuff that came with the kit. And I turn 3 or more times a day. But, sometimes when I touch them they are still sore. Is it normal for your ears to still hurt almost 5 days after you've had them pierced?



I'm 14. I had my ears pierced once when I was in 5th grade and I don't remember them hurting 5 days after I had them pierced.



If you want to know. I didn't take good care of them when I was in 5th grade so they healed up. And I never really thought about havng them repierced until like a month ago and I just finally got it done.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes that is normal. Keep using the cleaning stuff. They say though that you should only clean them once or twice a day. The more you touch then the more they'll get irritated. So, try to avoid it. If they keep hurting and you see redness around your ears you should go to a doctor. They'll tell you if you have a infection or not.



Also, maybe next time you should go to a professional, and get them done..



HOPE THIS HELPS!



</answer>

<question>



Need some advice about a nose ring and please be serious!?



I would love to get a nose ring but I'm scared to death!! Is it better to get a stud when you get it pierced instead of a screw? I just need a little advice from someone who's been there and done this. thanks



</question>



<answer from>



M G
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



my friend got one, said it didnt really hurt, but i think it might



</answer>



<answer from>



Ms SUPERHYPHY
Member since: 10 January 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it doesnt hurt at all..u only feel it when the needle goes through your cartalidge. its beter to get a stud,screws are more complicated and studs are easier to put in and out.



</answer>



<answer from>



heylivhe...
Member since: 24 August 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Get a stud for sure because they won't snag as easy.



The piercing takes no more than like a millisecond. The pain is no more than a second, just because it's going through cartilage, but it's totally tolerable.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tankgirl
Member since: 30 January 2008
Total points: 2387 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a ring put in mine after they pierced it. To me, it heals better because it allows you to move the ring through the piercing as it heals, thus avoiding any scar tissue from building up around the inside. I have had mine for nearly ten years and have never had any problems from it. I cant stand the "screw" ends because they always tend to turn upside down and the end usually ends up sticking out of your nose like a little silver booger...



</answer>



<answer from>



i &lt;3 Michael Phelps more!!!!!
Member since: 30 March 2008
Total points: 4827 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



dont be scared. i want one too, but my mom is still 'thinking' about it. just watch some people on you tube getting their nose pierced, thats what i did to get over my fear.



</answer>

<answer>



I wear 4 inch stilettos every day to work. I also enjoy wearing them when on the weekends, so I pretty much wear them the entire week. That's not to say my feet are hideously deformed. I enjoy wearing strappy sandals in the summer, so I take my feet's health and appearance VERY seriously. I moisturize them every day and have pedicures every two weeks. I'm blessed (and cursed!) of having big feet, so I have less difficulty walking in really high heels. I also make sure they're never too tight. Also whenever I get a minute, I dangle or slip in and out of them to give my feet a little rest.



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



Glenna F
Member since: 04 April 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not sure if this will help you but as a tall girl I go to New York and Company they have all sizes but then different fits. For example my waist is a size four but with my long legs they would be high waters but at NY&CO i can get a size four and than ask for it in tall. Tall being the fit that i earlier mentioned and since most jeans are unisex it might not hurt looking into. As for shirts same problem either opt for tanks, short sleeves or 3/4 sleeves or if there is a long sleeve shirt you just have to get scrunch the sleeves up a bit.  Believe me I know what ur going through and ppl say that clothing is easy for the tall and thin. Just have to be creative. Hope this helped.

<category>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



What is an example of a really expensive and well known women's clothing line?



No, I'm not rich and famous. I just need to use a brand as an example in a short story I'm writing. Thanks in advance!



</question>



<answer from>



Mia
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 452 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



lilly pulitzer? chanel?



</answer>



<answer from>



Olivia -
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 2409 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Juicy Couture



Gucci
Christian Dior



</answer>



<answer from>



Fa...
Member since: 30 April 2008
Total points: 597 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Calvin and Klein



Source(s):



uh me?



</answer>



<answer from>



Ms. Vintag E.
Member since: 25 May 2008
Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends.  Define expensive?



Dior haute couture is one "expensive," for an upper-upper class wealthy woman who loves beauty, quality and one-of-a-kind garments with honest HIGH status.  Juicy Couture and a lot of the other brands people have mentioned here are a totally different "expensive," for a middle-upper class girl who likes the cheap "status" that comes from flashing a name brand on a poorly-made purse or tank top from China.



Get to know your character.. and if her personality is very fashionable, get to know fashion. :)



EDIT: for reference, Juicy runs around $200 average for a dress.  Haute couture runs probably $30,000 average for a dress.



Source(s):



Love fashion.  And, yes, I do love Juicy Couture.



</answer>

<question>



Hollister coming to London! ?



Ahh i'm super happy! I was in my local shopping centre, Bluewater and i saw a shop is about to become Hollister! I was screaming as i've looked on the American site and love the stuff. Does anyone know if Hollister are going to open any other shops in England?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I am in America, but congrats. I love hollister. their shirts and tanks are comfy, laid back, easy to wear, and super cute. I love their jeans and jackets too! Better save up for some shopping! If hollister is going to open anywhere else in England, it would be in a big city, big shopping centers. Hollister and Abercrombie stores usually don't open in rural areas or small towns or tiny places.



</answer>

<question>



Is this girly for a guy?



i am buying promise rings for me and my boyfriend but my mom says the ring is too girly for a guy. What do you think?
http://www.limogesjewelry.com/Custom.asp...

how about this one?
http://www.limogesjewelry.com/Custom.asp...



</question>



<answer from>



aine Spook
Member since: 28 January 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



tough question, it's kind of opinion-oriented, I'd say, but if I may add my two cents, I'd say the top one is very feminine, and the bottom one less so. Now, hmm, well depending on what kind of guy your boyfriend is, if he's a jock-esque type, I'd say he'd have qualms wearing either one, but perhaps the second one if you said "pretty-please" and batted your eyelashes a bit. (lol?) 
Actually, now that I think about it. It'd most likely come down to self esteem, if he's more self conscious, lean to the second one, if not, perhaps the first one? Maybe he would be okay wearing an effeminate ring from you? Just take a bit, think about how he is, and rate it on a scale of the esteem and testosterone, more testosterone? lean towards a different one or the second one, less testosterone, you'd have more leeway.
(I personally think the top one's purdier, but I'm a really feminine guy, so meh, maybe you'd be better off with the second one as a safe side? Think about it! =D)



Source(s):



The madness within! ;D



</answer>

pleasehe...
Member since: 08 June 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think some people could pull it off, if teamed with skinny jeans and a plain top. I love the ribbed edging on it!!!!!

The material of that jacket does look fairly cheap though as it is really shiny! I dont think it is worth £45 personally.

If you want you could get a darkish brown coloured one, as this wont look "biker chic" and is really fashionable! You just have to look around until you find the perfect one, dont just go buyin the first one you see (unless you really love it).

Hope I've helped, xx



</answer>

Everytime i take off my shoes i nearly DIE with the stink!!

All i have is me and my stinky feet!

<answer from>



leilahns...
Member since: 27 April 2008
Total points: 2532 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you tried seeing your doctor about this? Since it is a condition you seem very concerned about I would think you have tried the over the counter products available at the local pharmasists? There can be a few reasons for your problem. One may be genetic. could be an infection. Only a doctor can tell you for sure. I doubt your parents are ashamed of you though. Unles it is happening because you don't wash your feet, but maybe they feel sorry for you that you have this problem. Don't worry, you'll find a solution.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AhmizGYvZhc3BQP.lGTO3M0GBgx0134.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk34480.txt</current file name>



<category>



Beauty & Style



Fashion & Accessories



</category>



<question from>



suzzie sue
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is it possible to turn  a yellow dress  into aqua



i bought this yellow dress but i want to turn it into aqua.does anyone know where i can get the aqua colour and what i will need to do.
cheers



</question>



<answer from>



Elle
Member since: 28 January 2008



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You may be able to dye the dress but it depends on what fabric it's made of - natural fibres absorb dyes much better than synthetics, so if it's a man-made fabric you may not get the colour that you want.

Finding a dye shouldn't be too difficult. We suggest that you head for Woolworth's, Robert Dyas or John Lewis. Most of them are very easy to use, you'll just need to buy some salt (which will help fix the dye to the fabric) and put everything into the washing machine. Bear in mind when you're choosing the colour though that your dress is yellow not white. That means that the colours will mix together and you'll end up with a very different shade to that on the box.

The ELLE team



</answer>

Kaitlyn
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 445 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you have a long torso and shorter legs, go for a higher wasteband, like mid rise or high waist jeans. This elongates your legs and shortens your torso, balancing you out a bit and slimming your silohuette. Also, heels under a longer flare jean would lengthen your legs as long as the heel isn't too visible under the jean.



</answer>



<answer from>



Go Team!

Total points: 1187 (Level 3)

<answer from>



Loveless
Member since: 08 June 2008
Total points: 466 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lmao I agree, peoplecan be mean! Just dont go around saying your a scene kid, that sounds poseurish!



Hair: Get it razored, layered, long back, and a side fringe at the front. Keep it black mixed in with platinum blonde or neon colours using manic panic (m.p. is great for hair after bleaching, it heals it using vegetable based stuff!)

Makeup: If your not a pro, just keep to eyeliner (black, thick, and around the whole eye). After you get the hang of that use eyeshadow's and false eyelashes. Oh and dont forget the blush!!!

Clothes: Band tee's, retro tees, any tee basically thats in neon colours, match it with black/blue/colourful skinny jeans (hot topic, d-tox), or you can go with skirts with leggings (stripes are popular!) and perhaps once in a while tutus!(claires)

Room colours: Any colours,hot pink/ neon green look great! Or perhaps black && white.

Extras: Must have are bows! for your hair, you can get them at claires, and studded belts, long or super short neclaceswith stars or hearts, piercings such as septum/ears/lip rings, extensions if your hair is short or you want to add colour. Myspace is a must have as well.

Hope I help, if you want to contact me for more info you can do so at www.myspaace.com/jazmox or email me at extremejazmo@hotmail.com



Source(s):



Me.



</answer>

<question>



Im dressing up as a bug and need a really good costume?



for my mates birthday we are dressing up as bugs and bug catchers(formally kids) but all i can find is ladybird and bee costumes is there any more bug/insect costumes out there? help please x



</question>



<answer from>



monroe_l...
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://cgi.ebay.com/COCKROACH-bug-mascot...



There u go!



</answer>



<answer from>



CARAMAC
Member since: 14 November 2007
Total points: 5724 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



As it's probably only a one-off, you won't really want to spend that much money, or go looking like an idiot either.

Try and use all the things at hand that you can... a black pair of leggings, or black fish net tights, a very short black pencil skirt, and a black/dark blue leotard, add a couple of black 'feather bowers' sewn individually around the back, from around neck to waist (legs !) , and you'll need some really big black sun glasses, to create the effect of BIG LENS EYES... a headband for antenae, some wings, and if you have leg-warmers (dark blue) these can go around your ankle calves, oh and you'll need black gloves to complete the picture.

Instant bug er...fly...

Have fun.. and don't get squatted, but if you have a fly squatter handy.. or take a black spatular.. then there's your bug catcher problem sorted too..

Caramac x



</answer>



<answer from>



ashy p
Member since: 11 February 2007
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

Well i think a black prom style dress would be good with some baby pink accessories or maybe fuschia pink accessories also. The whole black with pink is really a huge trend for this season.  Maybe a pink dress in a fuschia with black, or baby pink with black?



Well whatever you choose i'll see if i can find some dresses for you, to give you some ideas.



1. This dress is a lovely style strapless in stretch satin, with bow detailing also. It's a lovely flattering shape as it hugs in all the right places. I think it would be perfect for the event as you can dress it up really easily. Also if you do want to go with a pink dress, they do this in a fuschia pink colour also. 
http://www.oasis-stores.com/fcp/product/...

Now you say it needs to be like a prom dress, but in my opinion this style of dress is not the b-all and end all for a ball type event. As long as it's a dress for evening wear, you can wear what you want. http://www.oasis-stores.com/fcp/product/...

http://www.asos.com/The-Laden-Showroom/C...

This dress must have been made for your pink tie event because it is demure in the black colour and the prom style shape but has a little sash of baby pink at the waist, which gives it a lovely tickled pink feel, perfect for this event.
http://www.asos.com/Asos/Asos-Premium-Ti...

Wonderful dress, like the dress above but has a splash of fuschia, to liven things up a bit, you could put on some fuschia shoes and wear some hot pink nail varnish to make this fun and flirty in pink.
http://www.asos.com/Asos/Asos-Contrast-T...

This dress is so up to date because the asymmetric shoulder was seen everywhere, from lanvin to stella McCartney for spring summer 08. http://www.asos.com/Cheryl-Cole/Asos/Aso...

http://www.net-a-porter.com/product/3156...

I thought this dress would be absolutely perfect if you want a pink dress, i know its a bit more pricey but you can wear this again and again and again or if not, you can give it to me :P lol

Lots of pink clutches

<answer>



Totes Umbrellas are truly worth the money.  After being fed up of £5.99 and hyper value cheap types of brollys always breaking.  I decided to fork out a £15.00 for a brolly. Dont get me wrong you have to protect the brolley from blowing inside out, face the main body towards the wind, and also drying the brolley out properly will help any rust get in joints.  When not in use store it in its protector case.

<question>



Could I be a model?



I am 14 yrs old and was wondering if had the potential to model
I am only 165cm (around 5'4) bt i wanted to know if i could still do modeling for like teenage clothes and stuff, or do like catalogue
I weigh 49kg (108Ibs)
My measurments are:hip 91cm (36") waist 61cm (24") bust 71cm (28")
i dunno how to add pictures so if someone can tell me how to i will then add them
I have borwn hair and eyes and olive skin "mediterranean looks"



</question>



<additional details>



why will yahoo delete the question if i add pics?



thx for the suggestions one of ma problems though is that i live in italy so i dont think they have like competions and sutff like that, at least, not as much! also i dunno how to approach ma parents about the whole thing as i have no idea how they will react, both ma grans have suggested i do modeling bt they are my grans so dunno how attainable they are! :D



some photos, hope it works
http://s326.photobucket.com/albums/k420/...



agh lol soz im adding someting again! the link above doesnt work, try this:
&lt;a href="http://s326.photobucket.com/albums... target="_blank"&gt;&lt;img src="http://i326.photobucket.com/albums/... border="0" alt="Photobucket"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;



</additional details>



<answer from>



sara...
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 1257 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



My friend Teah is a teenage model.
She is Hawaiian, and has dark skin, just like you too!
She is exactly the same measurements and height as you are, so I believe you would be fine for glamor modeling.
However, catwalk is only for the size ) 6 feet tall sort of women. A catalogue would most likely take you.
Do not cut your hair short! They look for length so they have something to play or work with on the shoots. 
Also, wear something fashionable to the interview. They need to know that their models have fashion sense off the sets. Always have a good personality!
You can look up catalogue modeling agencies in the yellow pages.
I hope you make it!
-Sarah



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thx for the advice! i dunno wt im acutally gonna do bt its  nice to know that if i wanted to i do acutally have a chance!



</asker's comment>

<answer>



i think you need to put pictures up, because to be a model, you need to look the part,
contact modelling agencies. look them up on the internet and post them pictures of yourself.
in the photos, don't wear a lot of make up and jewelry etc, you dont want to look too 'try-hard' the less the better.
you say you would like to model for a catalogue or model teenage clothes, you could also try girls magazines, like sugar and shout magazine, they hold competitions like, all the time for a lucky reader to become a model.
there are loads of opportunities out there, your still only young yet so dont rush into things.

also, if the agency won't let you model for them unless you 'loose weight', dont do it. just dont.

and... if the agency asks money to join, is not a real agency, YOU get paid to model, you dont pay them.

good luck =)

x



</answer>

<answer>



Possibly cause your dresseing in really dark colours ... maybe try a nice pair of jeans ... but rather than black go for a dark indigo blue ... more casual but still smart cause of the dark colour... get yourself some nice trainers or converse ... poloshirts are good ... but Fred Perry is quite a neddy make ... maybe go to republic or USC and try some other brands ... even H&M have reallly nice guys stuff ... get some poloshirts in different colours ... brighter colours ... lighter blue, red, and if ur confident pink yellow or purple?? Or you could buy a couple or white Ts and get some nice casual shirts to wear over the top open? I also suggest that rather than a zipper maybe try a lightweight jumper in a grey or black .... a good website is ASOS they have a great section for guys and have  a really good sale on right now ...lose the cap ... is it essential??? They do make you look more threatening and plus the give u bad hair and people cant see ur lovely face!!! Its hard to be specific ... but if ur sporty or into football etc try JD sports their guys stuff is nice  and they have nice lightweight jackets 
Its trial and error ... Dont be something you dont want to be ... you need to be comfortable but have a look online ... try different things on and find a look your comfotable with .... lose the cap and boots and give ur wardrob some colour and you should be good to go



Good luck xxx

<answer>



Here are the rules to being emo.
1. Listen to softcore punk music that integrates unenthusiastic melodramatic 17 year olds who dont smile, high pitched overwrought lyrics and inaudible guitar rifts.
2. Start wearing tight wool sweaters, tighter jeans, itchy scarfs (even in the summer), ripped chucks with favorite bands signature, black square rimmed glasses.
3. And for hair, ebony greasy unwashed hair that is required to cover at least 3/5 of the face at an angle.
And talk/write poetry about pain, and call everyone who isn't emo, conformists.



Source(s):



Urbandictionary.com and South Park



</answer>

<question>



Mastectomy Lingerie - opinions please?



I am considering designing a line of post mastectomy lingerie and swimwear and am curious as to what potential customers would want from these items of clothing.

Underwear for example - large bra straps? maybe a more feminine/possibly sexier design than what's available on the current market?

Swimwear - modest and block colours? or maybe a tankini style with bright bold patterns?

I believe women should still want to feel confident and stylish in their underwear after all they've been through with cancer. 
So ladies, what do you think? Please tell me what you'd look for and what you'd love to see in a design for the perfect post mastectomy swimwear/lingerie!
Thank you.



</question>

<answer>



Hi. I've had a mastectomy myself, and I answered this question when you asked it in the Cancer section.

Just had another thought though - I don't know why it wasn't my first thought since it bugs me so much.

When you produce your catalogue please, PLEASE have women who have actually had breast surgery  modeling the bras and swimwear. No existing catalogue does that, the products are shown on professional models with all breasts present and correct, usually with visible cleavage.

It would mean you couldn't use professional models of course, but so much the better - this way you'd have real women of all shapes, sizes and ages showing what the garments would actually look like. And I'd be your first customer!

And... you or someone else might like to consider designing outer garments for women who've had breast surgery. Me, I live in T shirts - not because I want to but because my surgery means that on my right I'm concave from a couple of inches below the collarbone. And in common with many, I have scarring which extends to my underarm and back. And I want all that to be hidden. But on my left side - same as it ever was! There's got to be a party dress waiting to be designed for me!



</answer>

<answer>



The ideas are good and what i have seen so far seems ok. I have to say i don't like the wallpaper on the homepage before you go into the actual site, but then that is personal preference. 
You need to have something that will catch the eye, it has a tendancy to be a bit wishy washy. I like the "Style Me" page a lot. Remember to always keep things clean and sharp as if you have too much going on the reader gets distracted and this can put people off. I also find, clean, easy to read pages often have more impact than ones that are crammed full. Good work and good luck with the future of it.



</answer>

<question>



Replica Or The Real Thing?



I am looking for a watch, particularly a Hublot Big Bang. The real one is around £7000 yet I can get a replica, with a Swiss ETA 7750 Movement, for £450. I have ordered watches from the guy with the £450 Hublot before and his watches really are IDENTICAL to the real thing, even down to the boxes & warranty etc.
Would I be daft to pay £7000 for a watch, when I could buy the same watch (visually) for just £450, and noone but me would know it wasn't genuine.
Advise please....



</question>



<additional details>



The website I saw replica on is http://www.realisticwatches.com 
Its as good as the real McCoy visually



</additional details>



<answer from>

Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 742 (Level 2)

<answer>

You look like a million other girls, there is not much style 'visible' on this pic and overall it just looks pathetic. Wearing glasses that hide half your face, are you ugly or something? To scared to look people in the eye?

Dear *Dancing Diva* (interesting name)
You asked what I thought of you style, and I said I thought that it was trashy. You asked us to be honest. If you wuld have asked to lie, I would have done that.
 I also said I don't know you, but now I have the feeling that you don't just look trashy, you also are trashy. Sorry, you asked and you got an answer. In your life you will have to cope with critisism and with people who judge you on your appearances and 'style'. Not everyone likes the way I walk around and thats okay, because I feel comfortable they way I look and dress. However, I also expect people not to judge me on how I dress and on a single comment I made, when asked about an honest answer. So please, don't do that.
Also, judging from the thumbs up I got, I suppose many share my opnion and my comment can not have been that lame. Don't get insulting, it does not favourably add to your *style*.
regards

PS: I can't be jealous about someone who is scared to show their face. I can only pity them.



</answer>

swelwyne...

<answer>



I like that kind of thing too... but there's goth. And then there's goth.

I don't think the shoes go to well with the rest of it and the T and hoody would be too much together as they're both elaborately patterned.



Having said that, I like all the individual things (shoes included) other than the T and the black and white trousers.

I had a friend who went through a goth phase years back and she looked like a walking Time Bomb (Hot Topic, I guess? - TIme Bomb is a UK shop) catalogue!

I'd suggest black Converses/Vans/Etnies/TUK/Underground/Ne... Rock/DC Shoes/Quiksilver/Billabong/Ripcurl shoes would be good, maybe with a hint of red and/or yellow (or whatever other colour you like).

As for the top, wear a plain black or dark (red/purple/blue/whatever other colour you like) top.

I don't agree with labelling, but scene is about neon and 80-s and 90s details everywhere... which this outfit isn't.

But it's your life - wear what you like.

I hope some of this is remotely helpful



Source(s):



Alternative in my heart



</answer>



<answer from>



manga freakxx
Member since: 03 June 2007
Total points: 5014 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think that style is really "in" nowadays (am I wrong? hopefully I am haha) so you're not going to be coming off as unique but rather a poser. If that's okay with you, go ahead.
Meanwhile, I'm not sure if it'll all go together or what, but I guess you can try.
I want to mention, though, that you should just get your own style. My personality would probably fit into the "gothic" label or whatever and I do wear a lot of black and wristbands or whatever, but I wear plaid vests and Doc Martens, plaid gray pants and a few dress shirts and ties. The only thing that I could say would even get close to "gothic" would be my ripped jeans and my (lack of) color pallete. But, anyway, good luck. Hope you find yourself.



</answer>

<answer>



that sounds perfect 
just keep the canopies very bright colors and sheer
get tons and tons of throw pillows and put some of them on the ground for a seating area

very very cool idea btw =]

<question from>



hearsage...
Member since: 23 April 2007
Total points: 218 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Silver chain and bracelet 295



I have a 54 inch neck chain with 295 stamped into it, their is something else stamped into it aswell but i can't make it out

and i also have a bracelet with 295 stamped into it
the size is, 31 inches long and "around" 12mm across (quite thick)

does anyone know how much thease are worth.."around about"?



</question>



<answer from>



simm101
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 9813 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think you mean 925 and that is its purity. The other marks would be the hall mark and maker. Silver is trading at about £6.50-7 an ounce and you are better off selling it on ebay as those figures are the best a jeweller will pay.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



cheers



</asker's comment>

<answer from>



Kayla
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 396 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sure, they are pretty in style right now.

The main question is how flattering they are. Skinny jeans usually tend to look best on skinny people, especially skinny people with a bit of height.

Even a slight amount of hip or butt can look large in tight, skinny jeans, and flare or boot cut is much better for balancing out your curves, if you have them. If you must go with skinny jeans, but are not rail thing, stick to dark denim, be it deep blue, black or a dark grey.



</answer>

<answer>



god do not take jeans! They don't dry for about 4 hours haha! In my opinion, the best thing to wear on your bottom half is a pair of shorts, especially if the weather's warm(ish)- your legs'll dry quicker that way. Also jacket-wise (if it's a bit cold), if you haven't got a water-proof jacket like myself i always take a leather jacket; the water literally just bounces off it.

the many many trips to Drayton Manor i've been on haha.

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



i think it would be ok if you wear a nice pair of jeans. NICE PAIR. which means, no wholes or rips or anything.

if you want to go dressy, get a simple dress pants, nothing that makes you look to old. look at express clothes, and H&M

<answer>



It's perfectly safe since they're only contacts. Just remember to put the contacts in the correct eyes and make sure they are both the perscription you need. I have naturally two different colored eyes, it's called heterochromia: http://i29.tinypic.com/i607qx.jpg%22



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=ArfgwPh_fQ27xHMTe7XsbWoGBgx0134.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk40269.txt</current file name>



<category>



Beauty & Style



Fashion & Accessories



</category>



<question from>



suzzie sue
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is it possible to turn  a yellow dress  into aqua



i bought this yellow dress but i want to turn it into aqua.does anyone know where i can get the aqua colour and what i will need to do.
cheers



</question>



<answer from>



Elle
Member since: 28 January 2008



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



You may be able to dye the dress but it depends on what fabric it's made of - natural fibres absorb dyes much better than synthetics, so if it's a man-made fabric you may not get the colour that you want.

Finding a dye shouldn't be too difficult. We suggest that you head for Woolworth's, Robert Dyas or John Lewis. Most of them are very easy to use, you'll just need to buy some salt (which will help fix the dye to the fabric) and put everything into the washing machine. Bear in mind when you're choosing the colour though that your dress is yellow not white. That means that the colours will mix together and you'll end up with a very different shade to that on the box.

The ELLE team



s



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=ArO9wvB8e_lSDPeKpWBZqi8gBgx2d29.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk40294.txt</current file name>



<category>



Beauty & Style



Fashion & Accessories



</category>



<question from>



Fi
Member since: 10 June 2007
Total points: 190 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Describe your style in one word?

<question>



Which tote bag should I buy for school?



I really like these 4 totes, but I can't choose! Help me..please?

Tote 1:
$39.50
http://www.hollisterco.com/webapp/wcs/st...
$39.50 (One in stripes..I don't like the solid color ones, they have open pockets.
I like it, but I don't like how it's $40. And I'm not sure if it has pockets, WHICH I NEED. I need to carry around an iPod Touch, and also a chocolate phone..so I need some pockets, I don't need them any more scratched than they are now. I want some money left over, to buy something else. I got $50 left from my stepsister.

Tote 2:
http://www.abercrombiekids.com/webapp/wc...
I REALLY like this one, because it has the zipper thing, that can hold my stuff. I don't like the light colors, so I'd get the blue or the navy. But once again, I'd like to buy something with the money left over, and there won't be if I buy this!



Tote 3-
http://www.ae.com/web/browse/product.jsp...
I like this one, and it seems pretty big...I like how I'd have $20 left over too, but I don't know if it has pockets...but it does mention two 'credit card holders'....wtf?



Tote 4:
http://www.ae.com/web/browse/product.jsp...
$29.50

I like this one, but its not my first choice. I'd rather get one of the other three...this one is a 'backup'. It has a zipper inside...which I like.

Which one should I buy?



</question>



<additional details>



If it helps any, I want to kind of "stay away" from american eagle because about 90% of my clothes are american eagle...and I didn't do it on purpose...lol.



"katiepie"- nobody is original. K'? I don't care if someone has the same bag, if i like it, then i'll get it!

<answer>



You could always try eBay for lots of fun, cheap stuff. They also have brand-name items at fractions of the original price. And no, not all the items are used yard-sale goods. As a matter a fact, eBay is connected with many online retailers. But if you're buying clothes from any online retailer, make sure to measure your size and also check out sizing charts. I hope this helps you!



Source(s):



http://www.ebay.com/



</answer>
